conclusion: Need to analyze the velocity-time graph to determine the distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval.
The graph shows the velocity as a function of time.
Velocity increases from 0 m/s to a maximum of 20 m/s in the first 10 seconds.
Velocity decreases to 10 m/s in the next 5 seconds (from t = 10 s to t = 15 s).
Distance traveled can be found by calculating the area under the velocity-time graph.
For the interval from t = 10 s to t = 15 s, the velocity is decreasing linearly from 20 m/s to 10 m/s.
Area under the graph from t = 10 s to t = 15 s can be calculated using the formula for the area of a trapezoid.
Velocity at t = 10 s is 20 m/s, velocity at t = 15 s is 10 m/s, and time interval is 5 s.
The area under the graph from t = 10 s to t = 15 s is 75 meters.
The distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is exactly 75 meters.
The final answer is less than 75 meters because the area under the graph is exactly 75 meters, not more.
